topics.title: Roadmaps as prototypes for strategy
topics.summary: Janna frames a roadmap as a prototype for strategy: the value is in the roadmapping process, surfacing assumptions and validating them with teammates and customers rather than treating the roadmap as a fixed plan.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces the show and Janna Bastow, highlighting Mind the Product, the Now/Next/Later framework, and ProdPad, then transitions into Janna’s career background and what ProdPad does today.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Formsort (low-code forms), Coda (all-in-one docs), and Amplitude (product analytics and growth loop).

topics.title: Building Mind the Product community
topics.summary: Janna explains Mind the Product grew from grassroots learning among product peers, emphasizing consistency, shared ownership, and expanding the network via community contributors and curators.

topics.title: Conference operations: mistakes, risk, and economics
topics.summary: They discuss the operational realities of running conferences—logistical failures, high downside risk, thin margins until scale, and why community-building is essential marketing for ticket sales.

topics.title: Becoming a better speaker and storyteller
topics.summary: Janna shares how observing many talks and working with a speaker coach improved her narrative structure, delivery, and rehearsal habits, including recording and replaying her own talks.

topics.title: Managing stage anxiety and audience dynamics
topics.summary: Practical tactics for nerves: power poses, walking the stage during tech checks, and focusing on supportive audience members; Janna also recounts early speaking failures and why audiences root for speakers.

topics.title: Why Gantt-style roadmaps fail; Now/Next/Later
topics.summary: Janna critiques timeline/Gantt roadmaps as forcing false certainty and constant date-shifting; she explains how customer feedback led ProdPad to adopt the Now/Next/Later model aligned with the cone of uncertainty, while still allowing dates when truly necessary.

topics.title: Handling dependencies, launches, and date needs
topics.summary: They cover how to coordinate with sales/marketing without committing to dates for everything, including separating soft launches from hard launches and using dates only for true constraints like regulatory or seasonal deadlines.

topics.title: What top product teams do differently
topics.summary: Janna highlights patterns among strong teams: sustained discovery, psychological safety, and effective retrospectives that enable continuous improvement and reduce command-and-control planning behaviors.

topics.title: Changing product culture in large enterprises
topics.summary: Janna describes enterprise transformation as “chipping away” at calcified culture via small pockets of adoption, internal advocates, and executive buy-in, noting how incentives for stability can conflict with innovation needs.

topics.title: ProdPad as a tool that enforces good practice
topics.summary: She explains how ProdPad supports transformations by nudging teams toward outcome-focused roadmaps and better habits (problem framing, outcomes, success measurement), making it harder to revert to feature/date-driven planning.
